dublin_core.dcvalue: This paper describes a metric that can be used to characterize the resolution of arbitrary broadband coherent imaging systems The metric is particularly suited to medical ultrasound because it characterizes scanner performance using the contrast obtained by imaging anechoic cysts of various sizes that are embedded in a speckle generating background accounting for the effect of electronic noise We present the theoretical derivation of the metric and provide simulation examples that demonstrate its utility We use the metric to compare a low cost handheld C scan system under development in our laboratory to conventional ultrasound scanners We also present the results of simulations that were designed to evaluate and optimize various parameters in our system including the f and apodization windows We investigate the impact of electronic noise on our system and quantify the tradeoffs associated with quantization in the analog to digital converter Results indicate that an f 1 receive aperture combined with 10 bit precision and a signal to noise ratio SNR of 0 dB per channel would result in adequate image quality
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T18:00:20Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2007-04-19
IEEE transactions on ultrasonics, ferroelectrics, and frequency control
Cystic resolution: a performance metric for ultrasound imaging systems.
